title: The Way Out of Easy
description: The guitarist’s latest live set of exploratory, atmospheric jazz shares sensibilities with 2022’s Mondays at the Enfield Tennis Academy. The vibe is laid-back, but it rewards rapt attention.

title: Mahashmashana
description: Josh Tillman is at his spiritual peak: The mood swings are wilder, the logic more tangential, and the songwriting might be the best it’s ever been.

title: Piedras 1 & 2
description: Condensed from a five-hour radio play, Jaar’s 2xLP weaves a story of Chilean colonial history, military dictatorship, and Palestinian erasure into a dizzying mixture of abstract sonics and avant pop.

title: Groovy Steppin Sh*t
description: An unlikely meeting between the South Carolina rapper and Philadelphia producer yields thrillingly alien results. It’s the rare perfect marriage of tough underground MC and nerdy beatmaker.

title: Night Palace
description: Phil Elverum’s first Mount Eerie album in five years feels like a culmination of his work over the past 25 years, making room for all his earlier selves and sounds.

title: Patterns in Repeat
description: Following the birth of her daughter, the accomplished singer-songwriter carefully unspools a homey, quiet record. It’s one of the best of her career.

title: “SPANK!”
description: The Detroit ghettotech crew’s first single on a new label drops it hard and makes the ground move.

title: “Bumblebee”
description: The Chicago rapper’s delivery makes it seem like he’s in a life-or-death time crunch.

title: “Magic I Want U”
description: On the producer’s lighthearted new single, her experience in EDM, digicore, and guitar music adds up to a frothy pop concoction.

title: “Holy, Holy”
description: The black midi frontman’s debut solo single introduces one of his most pathetic characters yet.

title: “The girl, so confusing version with lorde”
description: It’s a meeting of the minds, two great pop stars being vulnerable and self-aware while making a watershed moment in pop in the process.

title: “Von Dutch”
description: The first single from Brat has its heart in the club and its ass on a Harley.

title: Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes (20th Anniversary Edition)
description: An expanded reissue calls back to the tumultuous era that produced the New York band’s landmark 2004 debut, which posed desperate pleasure as a way of making meaning in a hostile world.

title: Virtual Dreams II, Ambient Explorations in the House & Techno Age, Japan 1993-1999
description: A spellbinding compilation of seldom-heard tracks from the 1990s revisits the moment when Japanese ambient music absorbed the influence of a rapidly evolving worldwide techno scene.

title: Plays John Coltrane and Langston Hughes
description: Over the past nine years, the guitarist’s hushed, hypnotic suite of koan-like pieces has gathered a cult fan base. It’s a perfect encapsulation of his music’s mystical, spiritual energies.

title: GAS
description: Finally reissued in full, the 1996 debut from Wolfgang Voigt’s ambient techno project deserves every second of its 92-minute runtime. It’s music to get lost in, meditative and mind-numbing—in the best way.

title: Troubadour
description: Originally released in 1976, the pioneering artist’s debut album is filled with countless moments of disarming beauty. It plays like a map of her musical passions, linking folk traditions with avant-garde innovation.

title: One Hand Clapping
description: Shelved for decades and now finally released in full, Wings’ 1974 Abbey Road sessions are intimate and exploratory, showcasing a seldom heard, anything-goes side of the former Beatle.
